linkTarget.anchoringText: A polymer flood in Bhagyam would limit polymer injection to the oil leg. This would promote sweep within a closer well spacing and avoid the loss of polymer to the aquifer. This is a change from the current process which uses peripheral injection. Two producers, B-113 and B-118, were selected as polymer injectivity test candidates as they were positioned in the central part of field forming a 5 spot pattern with the surrounding wells representative of the field water cut (Fig. 2).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Bhagyam – Field Production Performance

formatted-caption.caption-text: Bhagyam – Field Production Performance

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Well Locations

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well Locations

linkTarget.anchoringText: The surface facility was designed to give priority to high water quality, good provisions for sampling and the ability to verify the quality of the injection fluid. A provision was made to inject at temperatures above the wax appearance temperature in order to mitigate the risk of near wellbore wax drop-out. Some of the salient features of the surface set up were (Fig. 3)

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Major components of the Surface Facility

formatted-caption.caption-text: Major components of the Surface Facility

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: B-113 – Well Log and Completion Schematic

formatted-caption.caption-text: B-113 – Well Log and Completion Schematic

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Water phase-Injection History

formatted-caption.caption-text: Water phase-Injection History

linkTarget.anchoringText: Water Phase Initial injectivity in B-113 was zero, after which several attempts were made to increase injectivity as shown in Fig. 6.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Stimulation Attempts

formatted-caption.caption-text: Stimulation Attempts

linkTarget.anchoringText: Initially, wax precipitation was suspected, therefore a wellbore clean out with hot water along with xylene-diesel (XD) job was conducted. This improved the injectivity to 4 bpd/psi but with poor conformance as shown below in Fig. 71. Injection was continued for a week and a time lapse production log was recorded which indicated poor conformance.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: B-113 – Time lapse production logs (water injection phase) – No significant improvement despite multiple stimulations

formatted-caption.caption-text: B-113 – Time lapse production logs (water injection phase) – No significant improvement despite multiple stimulations

linkTarget.anchoringText: Polymer phase Continuous polymer injection was started @1000 bpd, polymer viscosities of 10-15cp observed @1500 ppm concentration, but filter ratios were generally high. The ITHP (injection tubing head pressure) continued to rise steadily at low rates as shown in Fig. 8. Attempts to stimulate the well were made, but no significant change in injectivity was achieved. At higher injection pressures an increase in injectivity was observed, albeit with a poor conformance.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: B-113 - Polymer phase-Injection History

formatted-caption.caption-text: B-113 - Polymer phase-Injection History

linkTarget.anchoringText: Polymer phase Continuous polymer injection was started @1000 bpd, polymer viscosities of 10-15cp observed @1500 ppm concentration, but filter ratios were generally high. The ITHP (injection tubing head pressure) continued to rise steadily at low rates as shown in Fig. 8. Attempts to stimulate the well were made, but no significant change in injectivity was achieved. At higher injection pressures an increase in injectivity was observed, albeit with a poor conformance. Production logs recorded at higher pressures showed a change in the injection profile, but the conformance was poor (perforations at the top taking most of the injection). At 2000 ppm, viscosities of the order of 25-30 cp (Fig. 9) were observed. The injection was continued for approximately three weeks at 2000 – 3000 bpd during which the ITHP increased to 900 psi. The conformance continued to remain poor throughout the remainder of the test.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: B-113 - Polymer concentration Vs Viscosity

formatted-caption.caption-text: B-113 - Polymer concentration Vs Viscosity

linkTarget.anchoringText: After pre-production, the initial injectivity results of B-118 were encouraging when compared to B-113. The production log showed a good conformance which is attributed to preproduction flowback. A baseline IFO survey was also recorded as shown in Fig. 13.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13

linkTarget.anchoringText: A local grid refinement level of (1/9th grid size of original grid size in X and Y direction) enabled capturing polymer rheological properties. Certain perforations were closed that were known to be non-contibuting based on the interpreted production log (reference Fig. 15). Fig. 27 presents plot of final match of model well head injection pressure against the actual well head injection pressure.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Distinct change in derivative plot of B-113 and B-118: indicating higher “kh’ and corresponding better injectivity in B-118 when compared to B-113.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: B-118 IFO during polymer phase - Good indication of resistance build up can be inferred from the IFO’s during polymer phase compared to water phase.

formatted-caption.caption-text: B-118 IFO during polymer phase - Good indication of resistance build up can be inferred from the IFO’s during polymer phase compared to water phase.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Although this test was not completely confined (in flux), the nearby producers were tested frequently to assess for any impact due to injection. All producers surrounding B-118 indicated a directionally positive response, albeit for B-144 where-in a distinct response was observed in oil rate and water cut (Fig. 18 and Fig. 19).

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Combined response of all the nearby producers to B-118

formatted-caption.caption-text: Combined response of all the nearby producers to B-118

linkTarget.anchoringText: Although this test was not completely confined (in flux), the nearby producers were tested frequently to assess for any impact due to injection. All producers surrounding B-118 indicated a directionally positive response, albeit for B-144 where-in a distinct response was observed in oil rate and water cut (Fig. 18 and Fig. 19).

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: B-144 quick positive response to polymer flood, WOR has dropped significantly from 6 to 3

formatted-caption.caption-text: B-144 quick positive response to polymer flood, WOR has dropped significantly from 6 to 3

linkTarget.anchoringText: There is significant variation in oil viscosity with depth in Bhagyam field; it varies from ~15 cp at crest to ~500 cp at the oil water contact. In order to capture this viscosity variation in the simulation model (Fig. 23), three oil components (Heavy oil, Light oil and Solution gas) were defined and the mole fractions of the oil components were varied with depth.

image-wrap.label: Figure 23
image-wrap.caption: Variation of oil viscosity with depth in sector model

formatted-caption.caption-text: Variation of oil viscosity with depth in sector model

image-wrap.label: Figure 24
image-wrap.caption: Shear thinning modeling in CMG STARS

formatted-caption.caption-text: Shear thinning modeling in CMG STARS

linkTarget.anchoringText: The well injectivity would be significantly impacted by the non-newtonian characteristics of the polymer solution in porous media. In order to decide the optimum level of grid refinement to capture this effect, simulation runs were made with different levels of grid refinement around the well B–118 (Fig. 25). In general, well head injection pressure was found to decrease with increase in level of refinement. The calculated fluid velocity in the grid cells increased with increase in level of refinement and hence level of shear thinning of polymer increased. It was observed that 1/9th refinement of grid size and 1/11th refinement of grid size produced similar results, hence, 1/9th grid size was taken as the optimum level of grid refinement for this case.

image-wrap.label: Figure 25
image-wrap.caption: Effect of grid size refinement on model well head injection pressure

formatted-caption.caption-text: Effect of grid size refinement on model well head injection pressure

linkTarget.anchoringText: During initial injection period, well head injection pressure at 1/3rd grid refinement was found to be higher than well head injection pressure with no refinement (Fig. 26). This behavior was observed as the level of polymer dilution in a coarser grid is greater than that in a refined grid during the initial injection period.

image-wrap.label: Figure 26
image-wrap.caption: Effect of grid size refinement on early time injection pressure

formatted-caption.caption-text: Effect of grid size refinement on early time injection pressure

linkTarget.anchoringText: A local grid refinement level of (1/9th grid size of original grid size in X and Y direction) enabled capturing polymer rheological properties. Certain perforations were closed that were known to be non-contibuting based on the interpreted production log (reference Fig. 15). Fig. 27 presents plot of final match of model well head injection pressure against the actual well head injection pressure.

image-wrap.label: Figure 27
image-wrap.caption: Model well head injection pressure and measured well head injection pressure match

formatted-caption.caption-text: Model well head injection pressure and measured well head injection pressure match
